headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, Greg.
componenttext: Hi, Greg.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Couple questions, as it relates to cash flow. I mean you’re clearly in a pretty strong cash flow position, notwithstanding the soft power market outlook. How much of that is coming from things like regulatory asset balances? How long do you have just so
componenttext: Couple questions, as it relates to cash flow. I mean you’re clearly in a pretty strong cash flow position, notwithstanding the soft power market outlook. How much of that is coming from things like regulatory asset balances? How long do you have just sort of benefit from those before they kind of run off? Is there also a benefit from bonus depreciation or any other things rolling into ‘11?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I am going to let Harvey deal with the bonus depreciation question, but I think you’ll see that we have been extraordinarily aggressive in holding down our O&M expenses. We continue to do that, we continue to expect that to be the case next year and by
componenttext: I am going to let Harvey deal with the bonus depreciation question, but I think you’ll see that we have been extraordinarily aggressive in holding down our O&M expenses. We continue to do that, we continue to expect that to be the case next year and by holding that down, reducing our capital program. We’ll continue to drive the free cash flow that we need to have and let Harvey deal with the bonus depreciation.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, just finishing up on the regulatory assets, we would expect that to continue for several more years. We still have the distribution deferrals in Ohio and some other things that are being collected to our rate surcharges.
componenttext: Greg, just finishing up on the regulatory assets, we would expect that to continue for several more years. We still have the distribution deferrals in Ohio and some other things that are being collected to our rate surcharges.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I am sorry, the question on bonus depreciation?
componenttext: I am sorry, the question on bonus depreciation?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did you benefit from it this year, by how much and is there an assumption for any benefit next year?
componenttext: Did you benefit from it this year, by how much and is there an assumption for any benefit next year?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, roughly about $180 million this year and next year whenever the Fremont plant is completed, we would expect somewhere in the $75 million to $80 million range.
componenttext: Yes, roughly about $180 million this year and next year whenever the Fremont plant is completed, we would expect somewhere in the $75 million to $80 million range.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question goes to credit metrics. As you talk to the rating agencies around credit, what are you target FFO to debt metrics and where do you feel you guys are relative to those? This is a question that I think is becoming something that people ar
componenttext: My second question goes to credit metrics. As you talk to the rating agencies around credit, what are you target FFO to debt metrics and where do you feel you guys are relative to those? This is a question that I think is becoming something that people are asking to a lot of the diversified names, so just wanted to know how you feel about your credit metrics relative to the current power market outlook?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don’t think that credit metrics are where they need to be. We are working to improve them. Obviously, generating free cash flow and the level of liquidity we have gives us near-term benefit. We articulated in the past our desire to sell some non-core
componenttext: We don’t think that credit metrics are where they need to be. We are working to improve them. Obviously, generating free cash flow and the level of liquidity we have gives us near-term benefit. We articulated in the past our desire to sell some non-core assets. Our merger with AYE is driven with equity. But you are correct, our game plan is to improve those metrics and we’ve been improving them on a quarterly basis and we expect to continue to do so. Jim speaks with the agencies quite often. So I think he can give you little bit more one-on-one flavor.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would agree with what Mark said there. Our goal is to incrementally keep improving those metrics on a quarterly basis. If we do sell some of these non-core assets, we’ll use those proceeds to pay down debt. So, we would expect to continue to see those
componenttext: I would agree with what Mark said there. Our goal is to incrementally keep improving those metrics on a quarterly basis. If we do sell some of these non-core assets, we’ll use those proceeds to pay down debt. So, we would expect to continue to see those improvements.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: One other point is that when you look over the utility side of the business, we try to keep their capital structure very closely aligned with the regulatory rate structure.
componenttext: One other point is that when you look over the utility side of the business, we try to keep their capital structure very closely aligned with the regulatory rate structure.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Okay, thank you.
componenttext: Yes. Okay, thank you.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is coming from David Frank of Catapult.

componenttext: Yes, hi, good afternoon, guys.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Hi, Dave.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions. One, could you give us an outlook on the retail electric market in Ohio, what are your shopping expectations or what are your expectations for shopping and opportunities both in your service territory and those of your neighbors? Are
componenttext: Two quick questions. One, could you give us an outlook on the retail electric market in Ohio, what are your shopping expectations or what are your expectations for shopping and opportunities both in your service territory and those of your neighbors? Are you seeing any new areas emerge or can you give us an update there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Without getting into the details, we’re seeing opportunities not only within the traditional franchise areas but throughout the state of Ohio. We’re aggressively pursuing sales not only here in Ohio, but elsewhere. I haven’t seen the tops of the mar
componenttext: Without getting into the details, we’re seeing opportunities not only within the traditional franchise areas but throughout the state of Ohio. We’re aggressively pursuing sales not only here in Ohio, but elsewhere. I haven’t seen the tops of the market yet.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you can see that in some of my comments. We were 6.3 million megawatt hours above last year’s period, a 45% increase. Half of those came from customers outside our traditional service territory and about a third outside the utility service terri
componenttext:
I think you can see that in some of my comments. We were 6.3 million megawatt hours above last year’s period, a 45% increase. Half of those came from customers outside our traditional service territory and about a third outside the utility service territory. So we’re very pleased.
It’s all about margin, where we can get the highest margin, if we can get that, and location outside of what would be deemed our traditional franchise territory, that’s where we would love to try to push it. Right now we are very pleased with what they are doing. They are structuring contracts, they are staggering them, they are giving us higher margin, and we would expect that to continue. We don’t see any reason why it would not.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, Tony, just your pick for who is going to win the governor election and thoughts on what it’s going to mean longer term to the commission there?
componenttext: I guess, Tony, just your pick for who is going to win the governor election and thoughts on what it’s going to mean longer term to the commission there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think either Mr. Strickland or Mr. Kasich to win. I assume you were only talking about Ohio because there are multiple states that we are involved in. I think it’s going to be a very close race. The numbers have it different ways depending on what pol
componenttext: I think either Mr. Strickland or Mr. Kasich to win. I assume you were only talking about Ohio because there are multiple states that we are involved in. I think it’s going to be a very close race. The numbers have it different ways depending on what polls you look at. So we will have a winner next Tuesday.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Carrie St. Louis of Fidelity.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Carrie St. Louis of Fidelity.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, good afternoon.
componenttext: Hi, good afternoon.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, Carrie.
componenttext: Hi, Carrie.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to turn and follow up on some topics. First of all, with respect to the non-core asset sales, any update on timing?
componenttext: So I just wanted to turn and follow up on some topics. First of all, with respect to the non-core asset sales, any update on timing?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re going to hold back by the end of the year. That’s fairly far along. On the Signal Peak asset, we’ve always articulated that as production gets up to the 100% level, we’ll accelerate that sale. They had a very strong third quarter. I think I
componenttext:
We’re going to hold back by the end of the year. That’s fairly far along. On the Signal Peak asset, we’ve always articulated that as production gets up to the 100% level, we’ll accelerate that sale. They had a very strong third quarter. I think I’ve articulated in the past we’ve brought in a new Chief Operating Officer who spends all of his time inside the mine. We’ve seen a dramatic increase in the production from Signal Peak.
So, on that asset, I would say sooner rather than later, probably we hope maybe in the first quarter of next year, not too much beyond that. Again, it depends on their production schedule. We just don’t want to get into a debate with the potential buyers to what the actual production level is. Some of the other assets might be not as far along, but we’re making progress.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to make clear one thing that Signal Peak is a very valuable asset. We are not exiting that business prematurely.
componenttext: I want to make clear one thing that Signal Peak is a very valuable asset. We are not exiting that business prematurely.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I understand. I was just going to say I saw on the press release that I believe some debt financing has been put there or a structure there. So, when you think about an asset there, does that debt would move off with the asset correct?
componenttext: I understand. I was just going to say I saw on the press release that I believe some debt financing has been put there or a structure there. So, when you think about an asset there, does that debt would move off with the asset correct?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we financed the original development of the mine. It was never our intent to be the permanent financing source. The market was attractive to do something. The production is far enough along that it’s no longer considered kind of a startup developme
componenttext: Yes, we financed the original development of the mine. It was never our intent to be the permanent financing source. The market was attractive to do something. The production is far enough along that it’s no longer considered kind of a startup development. Jim’s team was able to execute that, while the debt is still on our books, the cash now sits on our books. So Jim, you want to add any other -.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We put in place a revolving credit facility down at Signal Peak. No matter what debt is outstanding at Signal Peak, we have to consolidate that on our balance sheet. We had been funding that operation with about $250 million from our revolving credit faci
componenttext: We put in place a revolving credit facility down at Signal Peak. No matter what debt is outstanding at Signal Peak, we have to consolidate that on our balance sheet. We had been funding that operation with about $250 million from our revolving credit facility. So essentially, it freed up some of our liquidity, but once we sell the asset, if and when we do, it’s really like three areas that will help us. One, you will not consolidate that debt. It’s on the balance sheet right now, which is about $325 million. The excess cash over that debt that we get, we’ll be able to use that to further pay down debt. And as Tony said, it’s a very viable asset. We would expect that we would generate a gain on our investment that would enhance our retained earnings.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then turning to the disclosure that you’d be giving more information at EEI, what information is that and specifically, do you think it will include like the hedging outlook for 2012?
componenttext: And then turning to the disclosure that you’d be giving more information at EEI, what information is that and specifically, do you think it will include like the hedging outlook for 2012?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re going to just kind of take the question we’ve gotten today, kind of sit around the table, try to get a sense of what additional information people want and then provide it. I’m certain that Ron and Irene are going to get a lot of questions as
componenttext: We’re going to just kind of take the question we’ve gotten today, kind of sit around the table, try to get a sense of what additional information people want and then provide it. I’m certain that Ron and Irene are going to get a lot of questions as soon as the call is over and our intent is to try to address as much of that as possible.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Obviously, with respect to credit metrics which have come into focus. You mentioned your regulated opcos are capitalized in agreement with your regulatory structure. I think investors tend to quickly look at the consolidated metrics versus focusing on the
componenttext: Obviously, with respect to credit metrics which have come into focus. You mentioned your regulated opcos are capitalized in agreement with your regulatory structure. I think investors tend to quickly look at the consolidated metrics versus focusing on the different parts, which are capitalized differently?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So, what is the outlook at Solutions in terms of like metrics and what is your commitment there? My sense is that you guys have been very firm about maintaining investment grade metrics at Solutions, if not better, and I just wanted to get reiteration of
componenttext: So, what is the outlook at Solutions in terms of like metrics and what is your commitment there? My sense is that you guys have been very firm about maintaining investment grade metrics at Solutions, if not better, and I just wanted to get reiteration of that view from you.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think he’s stated it right on the button. We expect to maintain investment grade rating, if not better and our target is to move them to the better category.
componenttext: I think he’s stated it right on the button. We expect to maintain investment grade rating, if not better and our target is to move them to the better category.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Our next question is coming from Hugh Wynne of Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Thank you. Our next question is coming from Hugh Wynne of Sanford Bernstein.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. I was looking at your consolidated income or consolidating income statement I guess it is on page nine where you compare earnings of energy delivery services to competitive energy services...
componenttext: Good afternoon. I was looking at your consolidated income or consolidating income statement I guess it is on page nine where you compare earnings of energy delivery services to competitive energy services...

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hugh, could you speak up just a little?
componenttext: Hugh, could you speak up just a little?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I was looking at page nine, consolidating income statement there, noticed that energy delivery services this year looks like it’s going to contribute almost three quarters of earnings. Now, my question really related to dividend policy post merger
componenttext: Sure. I was looking at page nine, consolidating income statement there, noticed that energy delivery services this year looks like it’s going to contribute almost three quarters of earnings. Now, my question really related to dividend policy post merger. Some companies with similar composition of earnings will link the dividend to the regulated earnings of the company. So, I guess my question is this, how do you see the composition of earnings across delivery services and energy services developing post-merger? Second, what would be the guiding factors in your advice to the Board regarding a dividend policy? Is this one of the considerations or others have a greater weight in your thinking?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We’re looking long-term, probably closer to 50% out of the wire side of the business and 50% out of the generation side of the business. So, we’ll just see how that plays out. My own sense is, everything you just talked about will be something that we
componenttext: We’re looking long-term, probably closer to 50% out of the wire side of the business and 50% out of the generation side of the business. So, we’ll just see how that plays out. My own sense is, everything you just talked about will be something that we think about and consider as we try to design an appropriate policy and communicate that policy to our investors at some point. At this point, I’m not really prepared to discuss any of the specific things that we would look to, but obviously the proportion of regulated versus competitive would be part of what we would look at.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would only add that when you get to the consolidated company of FirstEnergy and AYE, you’re going to have a transmission piece in the middle that will be also throwing off substantial earnings and so that all has to get placed into the mix and until w
componenttext: I would only add that when you get to the consolidated company of FirstEnergy and AYE, you’re going to have a transmission piece in the middle that will be also throwing off substantial earnings and so that all has to get placed into the mix and until we get all of that finalized with the transition teams, we’re still a little bit ahead of the curve.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’d also just remind you that the impairment charges associated with the Lake plants, distorted that comparative impact among the segments for the nine months.
componenttext: I’d also just remind you that the impairment charges associated with the Lake plants, distorted that comparative impact among the segments for the nine months.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. Okay, thank you very much.
componenttext: Right. Okay, thank you very much.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you.

componenttext: Thank you. Our next question is coming from Jeff Coviello of Duquesne Capital.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Good afternoon, Tony, Mark. It’s John [ph] actually.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi, John.
componenttext: Hi, John.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hey, John.
componenttext: Hey, John.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hi. I just wanted to go back to your comments that you made a couple of comments I guess earlier in the call, one that sounded like there was no risk of a dividend cut, and then you also mentioned the need that you saw for credit metric improvement. Final
componenttext: Hi. I just wanted to go back to your comments that you made a couple of comments I guess earlier in the call, one that sounded like there was no risk of a dividend cut, and then you also mentioned the need that you saw for credit metric improvement. Finally, you talked a little bit about or you alluded to of more formal dividend policy that accounts for volatility after the Allegheny deal. So, my first question is, have the rating agencies commented on the level of dividend payout over the next several years, and in combination with the pace at which you need to de-lever to maintain that investment grade rating or that low BBB rating at FirstEnergy Solutions, can you talk a little bit about how you….

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I don’t believe so. Jim is shaking his head, no.
componenttext: No, I don’t believe so. Jim is shaking his head, no.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven’t had specific conversations about the dividend policy John.
componenttext: We haven’t had specific conversations about the dividend policy John.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t want to speculate, but I assume that if our cash flow wasn’t as strong as it was, we might have that question, but not with the cash flow we’re now generating.
componenttext: I don’t want to speculate, but I assume that if our cash flow wasn’t as strong as it was, we might have that question, but not with the cash flow we’re now generating.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: What did you mean by a more formal dividend policy that accounts for volatility? What did volatility mean?
componenttext: What did you mean by a more formal dividend policy that accounts for volatility? What did volatility mean?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the easiest way to explain that John is, when you think about a competitive business in which the market price, just even a couple of years ago was pick a number 50, now it’s 30. When you have that type of movement, if you had a policy that just
componenttext: I guess the easiest way to explain that John is, when you think about a competitive business in which the market price, just even a couple of years ago was pick a number 50, now it’s 30. When you have that type of movement, if you had a policy that just said you’re going to send a percentage of earnings out, then when the market is very, very good, the dividend is high, but when the market is not as good, then the dividend has to be cut to reflect that. I don’t think that’s the policy that we would endorse. We would be looking for something that would be able to be sustainable and be maintained in whatever economic environment we face for the long term. So that’s what we’d be looking at and that’s what I mean by it.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So that, consistent with your earlier comment, means that at the current level of dividend paid out in cents per share, I guess, effectively your dollars per share, that you’re very confident that that is sustainable based on the amount of de-levering y
componenttext: So that, consistent with your earlier comment, means that at the current level of dividend paid out in cents per share, I guess, effectively your dollars per share, that you’re very confident that that is sustainable based on the amount of de-levering you need to do and the target to maintain an investment grade rating at FirstEnergy Solutions. I was trying to understand what exactly you meant there, please.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer would be yes.
componenttext: The answer would be yes.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay. Thank you.

componenttext: Thank you. Our next question is coming from Steve Fleishman of Bank of America.

componenttext: Yes, certainly below $500 million.

componenttext: Because it looks like year-to-date the amortization has been about $550 million from Page 13 through the nine months, you know, the slide that you have with deferrals and amortization. Was that $550 million all being recovered with cash flow? Is that all being recovered in revenues?

componenttext: Yes, don’t forget that CEI’s transition cost recovery will be ending in 2010.

componenttext: Right.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Looking at the capital spending, should I assume that you guys have made a decision not to scrub any of the coal plants that currently don’t have either scrubbers or SCRs or is that a potential future call on your spending?
componenttext: Thank you very much. Looking at the capital spending, should I assume that you guys have made a decision not to scrub any of the coal plants that currently don’t have either scrubbers or SCRs or is that a potential future call on your spending?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t think we’ve made any decision related to that. We have transition teams working out, looking at the generation of AYE, what it would cost to increase their capacity factors and reduce down their forced outage rates. When that team makes a reco
componenttext: I don’t think we’ve made any decision related to that. We have transition teams working out, looking at the generation of AYE, what it would cost to increase their capacity factors and reduce down their forced outage rates. When that team makes a recommendation, we’ll be in a great position to answer that. Right now they are looking at both the systems and where would be the best place to deploy the least amount of capital to get the most bank for your dollar.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So the capital spending could go up if you decide to scrub any or all of the unscrubbed units, right?
componenttext: So the capital spending could go up if you decide to scrub any or all of the unscrubbed units, right?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. It also could go down. We elect not to spend money on our units because their unit is in a cost range and dispatching range where we wouldn’t spend it on our side. So it could go either way. Our game plan is not to again spend money where we can’
componenttext: Yes. It also could go down. We elect not to spend money on our units because their unit is in a cost range and dispatching range where we wouldn’t spend it on our side. So it could go either way. Our game plan is not to again spend money where we can’t get a more immediate benefit that neither of us could get independently.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: On your second quarter call you had talked at Signal Peak about targeting a production level of 600,000 tons per month. Is that where you currently are in the third quarter or can you give us a sense of what the production level is?
componenttext: On your second quarter call you had talked at Signal Peak about targeting a production level of 600,000 tons per month. Is that where you currently are in the third quarter or can you give us a sense of what the production level is?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the production level is a touch below that, but it’s on a ramp up. I think the raw tonnage in September was 900,000, but that’s got to be washed, so that was probably down 650,000, 700,000. The more important feature to me is it’s increasing
componenttext: I think the production level is a touch below that, but it’s on a ramp up. I think the raw tonnage in September was 900,000, but that’s got to be washed, so that was probably down 650,000, 700,000. The more important feature to me is it’s increasing dramatically every month now that we have someone that’s a mine expert sitting in the mine every day. We just decided that we had the CEO, John DeMichiei, maybe spread a little too thin. He did a fabulous job developing the mine, but he can’t get in the mine every day. The new gentleman is and he is doing great and you’re seeing that in the production levels.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: One of the production issues that I think we need to at least highlight for you is that we are now in the first longwall panel. That will be moved in March, April timeframe into the second panel. The second panel is a much higher seam. Therefore, if you get those types of production numbers, you get a much better clean product coming out because you’re not taking as much ancillary products along with you. So it really is part of this overall development as you move through the initial panel into the panels that will, in fact, be the long-term future of that mine.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Greetings, and welcome to the FirstEnergy Corp. Third Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. It is now my pleasure to introduce your host, Ms. Irene Prezelj, Director of Investor Relations for FirstEnergy Corp. Thank you. Ms. Prezelj, you may begin.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jackie, and good afternoon. During this conference call, we will make various forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor provisions of the United States Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cauti
componenttext:
Thank you, Jackie, and good afternoon. During this conference call, we will make various forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor provisions of the United States Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Investors are cautioned that such forward-looking statements with respect to revenues, earnings, performance, strategies, prospects, and other aspects of the business of FirstEnergy Corp. are based on current expectations that are subject to risks and uncertainties.
A number of factors could cause actual results or outcomes to differ materially from those indicated by such forward-looking statements. Please read the safe harbor statement contained in the consolidated report to the financial community, which was released earlier today and is also available on our website under the Earnings Release link.
Reconciliations to GAAP for the non-GAAP earnings measures we will be referring to today are also contained in that report, as well as on the Investor Information section on our website at www.firstenergycorp.com/ir.
Participating in today’s call are Tony Alexander, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mark Clark, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, Harvey Wagner, Vice President and Controller; James Pearson, Vice President and Treasurer; Will Byrd, Vice President of Corporate Risk; and Ron Seeholzer, Vice President of Investor Relations.
I'll now turn the call over to Mark.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Irene and good afternoon, everyone. This morning, we reported strong third quarter results that on a non-GAAP basis represented an increase over the third quarter of 2009. Like many of our peers in the region, unusually warm weather and the corres
componenttext:
Thanks, Irene and good afternoon, everyone. This morning, we reported strong third quarter results that on a non-GAAP basis represented an increase over the third quarter of 2009. Like many of our peers in the region, unusually warm weather and the corresponding higher distribution deliveries had a positive impact on third quarter results. However, as we review the numbers, the biggest driver of our strong quarter was the success of our retail strategy as we continue to move competitive customers away from POLR and into direct sales and government aggregation channels. We are not just selling more megawatt hours, but reducing shopping risk, as well as enhancing our flexibility to structure favorable contracts and our opportunity to maximize our margins.
As I walk through our results, it may be helpful for you to refer to the consolidated report to the financial community we issued this morning. Later, Tony will update you on the merger, the status of the recent POLR auction in Ohio and outline information on some of the factors that we expect to impact earnings in 2011. 
Excluding special items, normalized non-GAAP earnings for the quarter were $1.28 per share compared to $1.11 per share in the third quarter of 2009. On a GAAP basis, this quarter's earnings were $0.59 per share compared to $0.70, $0.77 per share last year. As detailed on Page 16 of the consolidated report, 4 special items decreased this quarter's GAAP earnings by a total of $0.69 per share. By comparison, special items reduced GAAP earnings by $0.34 per share in the third quarter of 2009. The first of the 2010 special items was $0.60 per share impairment as a result of the operational changes we recently announced regarding several of our smaller coal-fired plants. These changes will provide us with operational flexibility and cost savings that we expect to bring long-term benefits.
The second special item was $0.04 per share charge related to merger transaction costs. As in prior quarter, these costs continue to be expensed as incurred. Third was a $0.03 per share charge related to power contract market-to-market adjustments of certain wholesale power contracts. And finally, $0.02 per share related to charges resulting from our new stipulated electric security plant in Ohio.
I'd like to quickly highlight our key drivers of our third quarter non-GAAP results, starting with the positives. First, a 12% increase in overall distribution deliveries benefited earnings by $0.17 per share. Residential usage was at its highest level in nearly a decade and a 19% above the third quarter of 2009, the quarter with record low usage dating back to 2002. This significant increase was largely related to warmer-than-normal summer temperatures across our service area and the resulting higher air conditioning usage. 
Industrial deliveries were up 11%, primarily related to higher usage by steel and automotive manufacturers, many of which had idle facilities for some portion of the third quarter last year. With this result, our industrial customer sector has recorded year-to-date double-digit sales increases for the entire 9-month period of 2010. Commercial deliveries were 5% higher than the previous period.
Year-to-date, we remain slightly ahead of our 2010 forecast of 106 million megawatt hours.
While these results are an encouraging sign of that the economy continues to recover, we expect overall distribution deliveries to remain below 2007 and 2008 levels at least through next year. The second positive earnings driver this quarter was commodity margins, which increased earnings by $0.19 per share. A detailed summary of this item appears on the first 3 pages of the consolidated report, including additional information on megawatt hour volumes and prices.
As I mentioned, our competitive sales strategy focuses on direct sales and government aggregation, and our efforts in these areas continue to drive our success. For the quarter, sales by our FirstEnergy Solutions subsidiary were 6.3 million-megawatt hours above last year's period, a 45% increase. About 1/3 of our growth in the third quarter came from sales outside our utility service territories and nearly half of our direct sales came from outside our Ohio franchise area. We are encouraged by these signs, their continued positive direction and the overall strong performance of our retail group.
FES also has been successfully adding retail generation customers inside FirstEnergy's utility service territories, which resulted in a corresponding decrease in wholesale sales. Again, we want to put less emphasis on POLR sales and focus more on direct and government aggregation channels, where there is lower risk, flexibility to stagger contracts and greater potential to maximize our margins. We're continuing to expand in the new markets outside our traditional utility service territories and have acquired customers in Southern Ohio, as well as markets opening up in Pennsylvania.
For the quarter, Wholesale business was down 1 million-megawatt hours or 26%. Generation output for the quarter was 19% above the prior year quarter or 3.4 million-megawatt hours. The majority of this increase came from our fossil units. With increased generation output and higher sales levels, we also incurred higher fuel and purchase power expenses.
The third key driver to earnings this quarter was $0.12 earnings per share shift in benefit related to lower operation and maintenance costs. This reflects changes in employee benefit costs including additional cost recognized for incentive compensation and stellar restoration in the third quarter of 2009, collectively resulting in a $0.10 per share increased earnings. It is important to note that while there is an earnings benefit related to timing differences for incentive compensation accruals this quarter compared with 2009, on a year-to-date basis, these costs are not significantly different. Similar to 2009, these accruals will be reversed if incentive targets are not met. Reduced operating expenses, primarily at our utilities, contributed an additional $0.02 per share to earnings in the third quarter of 2010.
Finally, net financing cost reductions increased earnings by $0.03 per share. Moving to the items that had a negative impact on the third quarter earnings comparison. Lower investment income from nuclear decommissioning trust reduced earnings by $0.05 per share compared to the prior-year quarter. When we realized the significant gain from the sale of securities held in trust. These sales facilitated our strategy to reposition our assets to limit volatility risks. A higher effective income tax rate decreased earnings by $0.06 per share, and higher kilowatt hour excise and gross receipts taxes this year reduced earnings by $0.03 per share. 
As you can see, while weather certainly benefit our earnings for the third quarter of 2010, this positive was more than offset by reductions related to nonoperational items such as nuclear decommissioning trust and taxes. As I mentioned at the start, our strong third quarter results reflect the gains we've seen from our competitive retail sales efforts with our continued expansion in the non-franchise areas, as well as the shift of our customers from POLR to direct sales and aggregation. 
Finally, our available liquidity of $2.8 billion is approximately $500 million higher than this time last year. Taken together, our results continue to track our expectations. As a result, we are affirming our 2010 non-GAAP earnings guidance with $3.60 to $3.70 per share.
Now I'll turn it over to Tony.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. I'd like to provide an update on the progress of our proposed merger with Allegheny Energy and some of the auction activity we've seen over the past few weeks. Because we expect o
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and good afternoon, everyone. Thank you for joining us today. I'd like to provide an update on the progress of our proposed merger with Allegheny Energy and some of the auction activity we've seen over the past few weeks. Because we expect our merger to close in the first half of 2011, we will not be providing earnings guidance in December, as has been our past practice. To help in your analysis, in the meantime, we have included a list of key earning drivers for 2011 beginning on Page 17 of today's consolidated report. And I will also discuss those as well.
We will have additional information at next week's EEI financial conference. Once the merger closes, we will schedule a meeting to discuss 2011, as well as more details on projected merger synergies and initial expectations for 2012. Now let's start with the merger update. We continue to be encouraged by the progress we are making towards completion of the merger. Since our last call, we reached a settlement agreement with 18 parties to our Pennsylvania proceeding. This agreement provides additional benefits related to jobs, competition, service reliability and renewable energy. We are pleased to have addressed all of the issues raised by these interveners. And as a result, have their support for our transaction. The settlement is subject to approval by the Pennsylvania Commission, which continues its review of the case.
Maryland begins its merger hearings next week, and West Virginia, the following week. While these are the only states where regulatory approval is required, Ohio has agreed, as a part of our ESP order, that it will not assert jurisdiction over the merger process. And we continue to provide information to the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities to keep them updated. 
On the federal side, we provided the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission with additional information for their review and continue to provide information to the Department of Justice. We expect these reviews to be complete in sufficient time to meet the anticipated merger closing schedule. As you know, the merger has received overwhelming support of both company shareholders, and we believe our progress in securing the necessary approvals underscores the value this merger can deliver to our shareholders and other stakeholders. As we work through the merger approval process, teams have employees from both companies continue working to outline how our 2 organizations will come together. Through this integration process, we will identify best practices for the new organization and develop the implementation plans to capture the benefits of the merger. Some examples include consolidation of contractor services and material purchases, operating a single IT infrastructure and data center and other economy of scale, particularly in our generating fleet that could produce new revenue opportunities as well. The merger process remains on track, and we continue to expect to close in the first half of 2011.
As I mentioned, we received approval in August from the Public Utilities Commission of Ohio for our stipulated Electric Security Plan. The plan was supported by more than 20 different parties representing customers and communities in our service territories. We're pleased to have the ESP finalized and are working to implement its terms, including the competitive bidding process. Last week, our Ohio utilities conducted the first in a series of auctions to secure generation for the 2011 through 2014 timeframe. As you may know, the PUC release the results on Friday. FirstEnergy Solutions was 1 of the 4 successful bidders for a total of 20 out of 50 tranches across the 3 different auction products. At the S-1 10 one-year tranches, 7 two-year tranches and 3 three-year tranches. Overall, we're pleased with these results.
Another auction will be held in January, and the result of that auction will be blended with those from last week's auction to determine retail generation service prices for June 1, 2011 through May 31, 2012. From a competitive generation standpoint, we're on a very different situation today then we were in the spring of 2009 when our generation position was fully opened beginning June 1. We won 51% of the tranches in that auction, and today serve, directly or indirectly, an additional 26% of the auction load. Since then, we have continued executing our competitive strategy and lining up customers for our generating capacity. Currently, FirstEnergy Solutions has 1.2 million retail customers. Going into last week's procurement, we had more than 76% of our 2011 generation output committed to direct sales, government aggregation and POLR auctions. Also as Mark outlined, we continue to make progress securing customers in non-franchise areas, and importantly, moving customers from POLR service to direct sales. As a result, FirstEnergy Solutions is considerably less sensitive to the Ohio POLR procurement process and continues to participate in other auctions taking place in the region, further increasing opportunities to sell its power. Most importantly, with the Ohio transition completed, we have built a strong foundation for our competitive retail business. And this includes our focus on direct sales and government aggregation. 
Last week, we also completed the default service process to establish prices for Met-Ed and Penelec customers for the first 5 months of next year. Prices from the final bidding process that will be blended with the results of previous auctions and establish the default service price beginning January 1, 2011.
As I mentioned earlier, we will not be providing 2011 earnings guidance until after the merger with Allegheny Energy closes. However, I'd like to provide some thoughts on several key earnings drivers for next year. It may be helpful to refer to Pages 17 through 19 in the consolidated report as I go through these.
As I look at 2011, it's important to recognize that the company is still in the transition to competitive markets and building its retail platform. And while there are a lot of moving parts, there's a major change in our business next year as a result of the POLR obligation in Pennsylvania being replaced with the competitive market. So in order to get a baseline, we started by isolating the Pennsylvania POLR sales of about 29 million megawatt hours in 2010 and the PJM purchases made to support those sales of about 20 million megawatt hours, which will no longer be part of our cost structure starting in 2011. And then we looked at the drivers of 2011 performance without those sales and costs. As you can see, we expect our retail sales to improve as a result of the expected continued growth in this part of the business and somewhat higher pricing in 2011. This will be offset by expected higher RTO costs and higher retail expenses, which are primarily related to increases in our sales force and back office expenditures. Additionally, we expect higher purchase power costs in 2011, primarily for balancing and to cover a portion of the reduced generation from our own fleet. Fuel costs are expected to be slightly positive, again, due to the reduced generation even though we will experience some price adjustments. We also expect that Signal Peak may provide some uplift in 2011 to offset what otherwise would be additional costs. Our plans for next year, as I've indicated, assume that generation output will be about 70.2 million megawatt hours, which is down about 6% from our 2010 forecast of 74.6 million megawatt hours. This reduction is partly driven by the outage scheduled  at Davis-Besse, as well as changes in the in-service date at Fremont and the operations of our older coal-fire fleet, which we anticipate to be in a seasonal or idle status during the year. This drop in production essentially impacts each of the drivers I've mentioned. These are either positively, through lower fuel costs, or negatively, through lower sales. However, since we have the ability to increase production if economic conditions or additional sales warrant, we are positioned to take advantage of those opportunities should they arise. On the distribution side of our business, we're forecasting 2011 distribution deliveries at about 107 million-megawatt hours. This takes into account normal weather, but we've also provided a range that reflects different level of economic recovery. 
Capital expenditures are expected to be between $1.4 billion and $1.5 billion, which is significantly below the current year as we wind down our large construction projects at Sammis and Fremont. Because we've already incurred most of that capital cost and project extended completion is not expected to add significantly to the capital budget. The capital plan reflects about $100 million from mandatory transmission and energy efficiency project and costs related to the accelerated replacement of the Davis-Besse reactor head, which will add approximately $90 million to the budget. Based on our current estimates for 2011, we expect to deliver free cash flow of more than $500 million. 
As you know, our Board of Directors reviews the dividend on a quarterly basis. It is our expectation and goal to maintain the dividend at its current level. Following closing of the merger, we plan to develop a more formal dividend policy that will provide stability, sustainability and growth for shareholders in all market conditions. I look forward to seeing many of you next week at the EEI financial conference. Now, we'll be happy to take your questions.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Jim Pearson. Tony hit on it primarily, but if you think about this year, we're going to be in the $500 million range. That's where we expect to be. If you look at some of those drivers, from the earnings standpoint, those are noncash, the dep
componenttext: Dan, this is Jim Pearson. Tony hit on it primarily, but if you think about this year, we're going to be in the $500 million range. That's where we expect to be. If you look at some of those drivers, from the earnings standpoint, those are noncash, the depreciation and the AFUDC. So I would say, from a cash standpoint, earnings will go down $60 million to $70 million. We don't expect to have the interest rate swaps and we have a little bit of gains in this year. So when you back that out and then you add back in the $300 million, the $350 million reduced capital expenditures, you get in the same line as where we are this year.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, and then on CapEx and its lower level. Is this a more sustainable level of CapEx as you guys look out and what would cause those numbers to move around in '12 and beyond?
componenttext: Okay, and then on CapEx and its lower level. Is this a more sustainable level of CapEx as you guys look out and what would cause those numbers to move around in '12 and beyond?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, and this is Mark. One of the reasons we put it in kind of what i call the 3 buckets there is that, first, we think going forward on a standalone basis, we'd be somewhere between $1 billion and $1.2 billion. And that's what it shows for 2011. And then
componenttext: Dan, and this is Mark. One of the reasons we put it in kind of what i call the 3 buckets there is that, first, we think going forward on a standalone basis, we'd be somewhere between $1 billion and $1.2 billion. And that's what it shows for 2011. And then you've got that second piece, which are things that either RTP or the energy efficiency type programs, which are mandated by various authorities and then, of course, to got attachment and recovery mechanisms for the energy efficiencies. So that's a piece we have less control over. And then, of course, the third piece is we may have a particularly large project come into play. And as you know we elected to move the Davis-Besse head replacement forward. We think that was the prudent thing to do. So on a kind of a core basis, I hit somewhere between $1 billion and $1.2 billion. And depending on what the states want to do, depends on what we make do with the particular project, you could be kind of a little plus or minus around that. But certainly, going forward, I think going forward $1.4 billion, $1.5 billion would certainly be at the high end, with the base period about $1 billion to $1.2 billion.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we should be assuming that the guidance driver -- I guess on the 2010 guidance, the fact that you guys held the range today is because there's some pressure in the fourth quarter year-over-year that we should be thinking about or is it you just don't
componenttext: And we should be assuming that the guidance driver -- I guess on the 2010 guidance, the fact that you guys held the range today is because there's some pressure in the fourth quarter year-over-year that we should be thinking about or is it you just don't want to update the year at this point in time?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Another for looking at anything of a specific nature regarding the fourth quarter. Certainly, we had a very strong third quarter with the weather, but as I stated earlier, that was completely offset by some of the nonoperational comparisons. The big drive
componenttext: Another for looking at anything of a specific nature regarding the fourth quarter. Certainly, we had a very strong third quarter with the weather, but as I stated earlier, that was completely offset by some of the nonoperational comparisons. The big driver being the retail sales. But just like in the third quarter, we could have items, just by way of example, we can have taxes reversed back by like they did in the third quarter. Another example would be the acceleration of Davis-Besse O&M, which was not included in the prior estimates, and we're working through that with our engineers. So we think it's appropriate to stay within that earnings guidance range, and we still have 2.5 months left in the year. And so that, it's not that we didn't look at it, we're just comfortable with it being in that range.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess one last question, Tony. On the dividend comment, when you plan to evaluate after the merger closes, does that mean the absolute level is under consideration or just a strategic payout ratio and follow-up processes as to how you address the di
componenttext: And I guess one last question, Tony. On the dividend comment, when you plan to evaluate after the merger closes, does that mean the absolute level is under consideration or just a strategic payout ratio and follow-up processes as to how you address the dividend?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Dan, I think I mentioned this several times. The absolute level, obviously, is determined by the board. But I'm comfortable with the level we're at. I'm comfortable that this is sustainable following the merger with Allegheny, and it's more related to
componenttext: And Dan, I think I mentioned this several times. The absolute level, obviously, is determined by the board. But I'm comfortable with the level we're at. I'm comfortable that this is sustainable following the merger with Allegheny, and it's more related to as a combined company. And as we face volatility and other things in the market, we begin to design a dividend policy going forward that better reflects that type of operation.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Dan, this is Mark. I would only add that even in the current dividend payout ratio next year, even after paying it, we're projecting to be over $500 million of free cash. So the absolute level, as Tony alluded to, is not something we discuss.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jonathan Arnold of Deutsche Bank.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions for you on the disclosure you gave on what you won on recent Ohio auction, you seem to be more successful in the shorter-dated products than the longer-dated tranches. Was that a reflection of it being more competitive in the
componenttext: I have a couple of questions for you on the disclosure you gave on what you won on recent Ohio auction, you seem to be more successful in the shorter-dated products than the longer-dated tranches. Was that a reflection of it being more competitive in the longer pieces or a conscious decision to leave more of your longer position open? And I guess as follow up to that, in the past, you kind of filled in through serving some participants in the auction, what should be thinking on those lines on the back of this one?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'll let Bill Byrd answer the question for you, but from my perspective, I'm very comfortable allowing for the upside to materialize, which I truly believe is going to happen as the economy recovers and as additional actions are going to have to be taken
componenttext: I'll let Bill Byrd answer the question for you, but from my perspective, I'm very comfortable allowing for the upside to materialize, which I truly believe is going to happen as the economy recovers and as additional actions are going to have to be taken with respect to the older coal-fire fleet. So in this timeframe, I'm not uncomfortable with being more aggressive towards the front end as opposed to the tail end. As to your second question, at this point, we do not contemplate taking any action to acquire tranches from any other of the third-party winners. Bill, do you have any other color you want to add. I mean I wasn't at the auction, so I don't really have any sense for how the moving parts went and played out. But the overall result, quite frankly, is pretty consistent with where I believe the company's best interests are served.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: What Tony described in terms of solutions, winning the different products with sort of the strategic orientation going into the auction and then the auction process itself, you bid on all 3 products at the same time. It's a simultaneous auction, so it was just a call of value versus risk. And basically, where the different products were priced versus the risk and we ended up with more of the shorter-term products.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. Let me just step back during 2010 third quarter, we're almost coming off a record residential sales with the preceding year, 2009, being almost at a decade low. We forecast based on a normalized basis. So we would smooth out those kinds of o
componenttext: This is Mark. Let me just step back during 2010 third quarter, we're almost coming off a record residential sales with the preceding year, 2009, being almost at a decade low. We forecast based on a normalized basis. So we would smooth out those kinds of offsets. So I think that the answer is simply that we normalize our forecast and you will see that, that benefit that we get from the residential side gets stripped out. And that has an effect on the overall forecast. We don't take the residential increased 19%, and add then another 2% or 3-or-some percent to it. So we're very comfortable with the forecast. We think it's more than achievable. And We think it aligns with our overall strategy.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: What was that Jonathan?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: I'm trying to understand why given the sales are down strong 2010, why there wouldn't be just a negative skew to that forecast, why it's sort of flat number?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think one very clear reason is we're not a regulated utility and our group can increase or decrease that number. I don't know. Bill, do you have that?
componenttext: I think one very clear reason is we're not a regulated utility and our group can increase or decrease that number. I don't know. Bill, do you have that?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me go back to the distribution side of it. We're looking at, Jonathan, is we predict normal conditions and we're predicting some in the economy that could accelerate and have positive benefits to us or the economy can turn more negative on us like it
componenttext: Let me go back to the distribution side of it. We're looking at, Jonathan, is we predict normal conditions and we're predicting some in the economy that could accelerate and have positive benefits to us or the economy can turn more negative on us like it has over the last several years. What we wanted to try to capture as we look at drivers for next year is I still think we're on a fairly uncertain economic environment as to whether or not industrial sales will continue to grow at that pace they are or whether or not the economy will suffer some retraction. That's what we've tried to reflect there. While we're comfortable at a normal kind of basis, there's still a lot of uncertainty with respect to what the impact of the economy can have on our sales.

componenttext: That's how I'm looking at it. I think I'm very comfortable with where we're at. The amount of cash that the comp generates and its ability to cover that dividend, not only in its current form, but after the merger with Allegheny. So I'm looking more towards a policy as to how we can grow that dividend going forward.

componenttext: Eventually, that number reflects the market. This number for '11 is as we've reflected and our retail contracts will go over at the ratable pace at about 10% a quarter roughly. The POLR contracts expire at predetermined dates. They're more lumpy. componenttext: A couple of questions as it relates to cash flow. I mean you're clearly in a pretty cash flow the position notwithstanding the soft power market outlook. How much of that is coming from things like regulatory asset balances and how long do you have to sort of benefit from those where they kind of run off, and is there also a benefit from bonus depreciation or any other things rolling into '11?

componenttext: I'm going to let Harvey deal with the bonus depreciation question, but I think you'll see that we have been extraordinarily aggressive in holding down our O&M expenses. We continue to do that. We continue to expect that to be the case next year. And by holding that down, reducing our capital program. We'll continue to drive the free cash flow that we need to have and let Harvey deal with the bonus depreciation.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: My second question goes to credit metrics. As you talk to the rating agencies around credit, what are your target FFO to debt metrics and where do you feel you guys are relative to those? This is a question that I think is becoming something that people a
componenttext: My second question goes to credit metrics. As you talk to the rating agencies around credit, what are your target FFO to debt metrics and where do you feel you guys are relative to those? This is a question that I think is becoming something that people are asking to a lot of the diversified names. So I just wanted to know how you feel about your credit metrics relative to the current power market outlook.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't think that our credit metrics are where they need to be. We're working to improve them, obviously, generating free cash flow in the level of liquidity we have gives us near-term benefit. We've articulated in the past our desire to sell some non-c
componenttext: We don't think that our credit metrics are where they need to be. We're working to improve them, obviously, generating free cash flow in the level of liquidity we have gives us near-term benefit. We've articulated in the past our desire to sell some non-core assets. Our merger with AYE is driven with equity. But you're correct. Our game plan is to improve those metrics and we've been improving them on a quarterly basis. And we expect to continue to do so. And Jim speaks with the agencies quite often, so I think he can give you a little bit more one-on-one flavor.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, I would agree with what Mark said there. Our goal is to incrementally improving those metrics on a quarterly basis. And if we do sell some of these non-core assets, we'll use those proceeds to pay down debt. So we would expect to continue to see tho
componenttext: Greg, I would agree with what Mark said there. Our goal is to incrementally improving those metrics on a quarterly basis. And if we do sell some of these non-core assets, we'll use those proceeds to pay down debt. So we would expect to continue to see those improvements.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: One other point is that when you look over the utility side of the business, we try to keep their capital structure very closely in line with the regulatory rate structure.

Are you seeing any new areas emerge or can you give us an update there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Without getting into the details, we're seeing opportunities not only within the traditional franchise areas but throughout the state of Ohio, and we're aggressively pursuing sales not only here in Ohio, but elsewhere. There isn't a -- I haven't seen the
componenttext: Without getting into the details, we're seeing opportunities not only within the traditional franchise areas but throughout the state of Ohio, and we're aggressively pursuing sales not only here in Ohio, but elsewhere. There isn't a -- I haven't seen the top of the market yet.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you can see in some of my comments. We were 6.3 million megawatt hours above last year's period, a 45% increase. And half of those came from customers outside our traditional service territory, and about 1/3 third outside the utility service terri
componenttext: I think you can see in some of my comments. We were 6.3 million megawatt hours above last year's period, a 45% increase. And half of those came from customers outside our traditional service territory, and about 1/3 third outside the utility service territory. So we're very pleased. It is all about margin. Where we can get the highest margin. And if we get that location outside be our traditional franchise territory. That's where we would try to push it. But right now, we're very pleased with what they're doing. They're structuring contracts. They're staggering them. They're giving us higher margin. And we would expect that to continue. We don't see any reason why it would not.

componenttext: I think either Mr. Strickland or Mr. Kasich will win. And I assume you're only talking about Ohio because there are multiple states that we are involved in. I think it's going to be a very close race. The numbers have it different ways depending on what polls you look at. So we would have a winner next Tuesday.

componenttext: I just wanted to turn and follow up on some topics. First of all, with respect to the non-core asset sales, any update on timing?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, Kerry. We think that we are going to sell a portion of the Fremont asset. Asset by the end of the year. That's fairly long. On the Signal Peak asset, we've always articulated as production gets up to the 100% level, we'll accelerat
componenttext: That's a good question, Kerry. We think that we are going to sell a portion of the Fremont asset. Asset by the end of the year. That's fairly long. On the Signal Peak asset, we've always articulated as production gets up to the 100% level, we'll accelerate that sale. They had a very strong third quarter. I think I've articulated in the past, we have brought in a new Chief Operating Officer who spends all of his time inside the mine. We've seen a dramatic increase in the production from Signal Peak. And so on that asset, I would say sooner rather than later. Probably, we hope maybe in the first quarter of next year, not too much beyond that. But again, it depends on their production schedule. We just don't want to get into a debate with the potential buyers to what the actual production level is. And some of the other assets might not be as far as along, but we're making progress.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: this is Jim. We put in place a revolving credit facility down at Signal Peak. No matter what debt's outstanding at Signal Peak, we have to consolidate that on our balance sheet. We have been funding that operations with about $250 million from our revolvi
componenttext: this is Jim. We put in place a revolving credit facility down at Signal Peak. No matter what debt's outstanding at Signal Peak, we have to consolidate that on our balance sheet. We have been funding that operations with about $250 million from our revolving credit facility. So essentially, it freed up some of our liquidity. But once we sell the asset, if and when we do, it's really like 3 areas that will help us. One, you will not consolidate that, that ought to talk about Europe, which is about $325 million. The excess cash over that debt that we get, we'll be able to use that to further pay down debt. And as Tony said, it's a very valuable asset. We would expect it would generate a gain on our investment that would enhance or retain earnings.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess the easiest way to explain that John is when you think about a competitive business in which the market price just even here a couple of years ago, pick a number. 15, now it's 30. When you have that type of movement, if you have a policy tha
componenttext: Well, I guess the easiest way to explain that John is when you think about a competitive business in which the market price just even here a couple of years ago, pick a number. 15, now it's 30. When you have that type of movement, if you have a policy that just says you're going to send a percentage of earnings out then when the market is very, very good, the dividend as high but the market is not as good, the dividend has to be cut to reflect that. I don't think that that's a policy that we would endorse. We would be looking for something that would be able to sustainable and be maintained in whatever economic environment we face for the long term. So that's what we'd be looking at, and that's what I mean by it.

componenttext: I think the production level is a touch below that but it's on a ramp up. I think the raw tonnage is in September was 900,000, but that's got to be washed. So that was probably down 650,000 to 700,000. The more important feature to me is it's increasing dramatically every month now that we have someone that's a mine expert sitting in the mine every day. We just decided that we had the CEO John maybe spread a little too thin. He did a fabulous job developing the mine, but he can't get in the mine every day. The new gentleman is and he's doing great, and you're seeing that in the production levels.

componenttext: One of the production issues that I think we need to highlight for you is we are now in the first longwall panel. That will be moved in March April timeframe into the second panel. Second panel is a much more, much higher seam. And therefore, if  you to get those types of production numbers, you get a much better clean product coming out because you're not taking as much ancillary products along with you. So it really is part of this overall development as we move through the initial panel into the panels that will in fact be the long-term future of that mine.
