componenttext: Well, a large driver of it, obviously, is the reduction in the capital budget. That will be a significant component of it, and I think maybe Jim can give you a little more clarity with respect to how the rest of it falls together.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Jim Pearson. Tony hit on it primarily, but if you think about this year, we're going to be in the $500 million range. That's where we'd expect to be. If you look at some of those drivers from the earnings standpoint, those are noncash, the de
componenttext: Dan, this is Jim Pearson. Tony hit on it primarily, but if you think about this year, we're going to be in the $500 million range. That's where we'd expect to be. If you look at some of those drivers from the earnings standpoint, those are noncash, the depreciation and the AFUDC. So I would say from a cash standpoint, earnings will go down $60 million to $70 million. We don't expect to have the interest rate swaps, and we had a little bit of gains in this year. So when you back that out and then you add back in the $300 million to $350 million reduced capital expenditures, you -- it’s in the same line as where we are this year.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then on the CapEx, it’s a lower level. Is this a more sustainable level of CapEx as you guys look out, and what would cause those numbers to move around in '12 and beyond?
componenttext: Okay. And then on the CapEx, it’s a lower level. Is this a more sustainable level of CapEx as you guys look out, and what would cause those numbers to move around in '12 and beyond?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Mark. One of the reasons we put it in kind of what I'll call the 3 buckets there is that, first, we think going forward, on a standalone basis, we'd be somewhere between $1 billion and $1.2 billion, and that's what it shows for 2011. And then
componenttext: Dan, this is Mark. One of the reasons we put it in kind of what I'll call the 3 buckets there is that, first, we think going forward, on a standalone basis, we'd be somewhere between $1 billion and $1.2 billion, and that's what it shows for 2011. And then you've got that second piece, which are things that either RTEP or the energy efficiency type programs, which are mandated by various authorities. And then, of course, you've got Attachment O and recovery mechanisms for the energy efficiencies. So that's a piece we have less control over. And then, of course, the third piece is where we may have a particularly large project come into play, and as you know, we elected to move the Davis-Besse head replacement forward. We think that was a prudent thing to do. So on a kind of a core basis, it's somewhere between $1 billion and $1.2 billion, and then depending on what the states want to do, it depends on what we make do with a particular project. You could be kind of a little plus or minus around that. But certainly, going forward, I think $1.4 billion, $1.5 billion would certainly be at the high end, with the base period about $1 billion to $1.2 billion.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And we should be assuming that the guidance driver -- I guess on the 2010 guidance, the fact that you guys held the range today, is that because there's some pressure in the fourth quarter year-over-year that we should be thinking about? Or is it yo
componenttext: Okay. And we should be assuming that the guidance driver -- I guess on the 2010 guidance, the fact that you guys held the range today, is that because there's some pressure in the fourth quarter year-over-year that we should be thinking about? Or is it you just didn't want to update the year at this point in time in the year?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if we're looking at anything of a specific nature regarding the fourth quarter. I mean, certainly, we had a very strong third quarter with the weather, but as I stated earlier, that was completely offset by some of the nonoperational comparis
componenttext: I don't know if we're looking at anything of a specific nature regarding the fourth quarter. I mean, certainly, we had a very strong third quarter with the weather, but as I stated earlier, that was completely offset by some of the nonoperational comparisons, the big driver being the retail sales. But just like in the third quarter, we could have items -- just by way of example, we could have taxes reversed back around like they did in the third quarter. Another example would be the acceleration of Davis-Besse O&M, which was not included in prior estimates, and we're working through that with our engineers. So we think it's appropriate to stay within that earnings guidance range, and we still have 2.5 months left in the year. And so it's not that we didn't look at it. We're just comfortable with it being in that range.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess one last question. Tony, on the dividend comment, when you plan to evaluate after the merger closes, does that mean the absolute level is under consideration or just a strategic payout ratio and thought process as to how you address
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess one last question. Tony, on the dividend comment, when you plan to evaluate after the merger closes, does that mean the absolute level is under consideration or just a strategic payout ratio and thought process as to how you address the dividend?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Dan, I think I’ve mentioned this several times. The absolute level, obviously, is determined by the board, but I'm comfortable with the level we're at. I'm comfortable that it is sustainable following the merger with Allegheny, and it's more relate
componenttext: Yes, Dan, I think I’ve mentioned this several times. The absolute level, obviously, is determined by the board, but I'm comfortable with the level we're at. I'm comfortable that it is sustainable following the merger with Allegheny, and it's more related to as a combined company. And as we face volatility and other things in the market, we begin to design a dividend policy going forward that better reflects that type of operation.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Dan, this is Mark. I would only add that even at the current dividend payout ratio next year, even after paying it, we're projecting to be over $500 million of free cash. So the absolute level, as Tony alluded to, is not something we discuss.
componenttext: Dan, this is Mark. I would only add that even at the current dividend payout ratio next year, even after paying it, we're projecting to be over $500 million of free cash. So the absolute level, as Tony alluded to, is not something we discuss.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Jonathan Arnold of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jonathan Arnold of Deutsche Bank.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions. Firstly, on the disclosure you gave on what you won in the recent Ohio auction, you seem to be more successful in the shorter-dated products than the longer-dated tranches. Was that a reflection of it being more competitive in
componenttext: I had a couple of questions. Firstly, on the disclosure you gave on what you won in the recent Ohio auction, you seem to be more successful in the shorter-dated products than the longer-dated tranches. Was that a reflection of it being more competitive in the longer pieces or a conscious decision to leave more of your longer position open? And I guess as a follow-on to that, in the past, you kind of filled in through serving some other participants in the auction. What should we be thinking on those lines on the back of this one?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll let Bill Byrd answer the question for you, but from my perspective, I'm very comfortable allowing for the upside to materialize, which I truly believe is going to happen as the economy recovers and as additional actions are going to have to be
componenttext: Well, I'll let Bill Byrd answer the question for you, but from my perspective, I'm very comfortable allowing for the upside to materialize, which I truly believe is going to happen as the economy recovers and as additional actions are going to have to be taken with respect to the older coal-fired fleet. So in this time frame, I'm not uncomfortable with being more aggressive towards the front end as opposed to the tail end. As to your second question, at this point, we do not contemplate taking any action to acquire tranches from any other third-party winners. Bill, do you have any color you want to add? I mean, I wasn't at the auction itself, so I don't really have any sense for how the moving parts went and played out, but the overall result, quite frankly, is pretty consistent with where I believe the company's best interests are served.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And what Tony described in terms of solutions, winning of the different products was sort of the strategic orientation going into the auction, and in the auction process itself, you bid on all 3 products at the same time. It's a simultaneous auction, so i
componenttext: And what Tony described in terms of solutions, winning of the different products was sort of the strategic orientation going into the auction, and in the auction process itself, you bid on all 3 products at the same time. It's a simultaneous auction, so it was just the call of value versus risk and basically where the different products were priced versus the risk. And we ended up with more of the shorter-term products.

componenttext: Yes, okay. And then just one other small thing I had on the distribution driver for next year. You have the sales expected to be down. I mean, you identified deliveries as sort of could be a bit negative, could be a bit positive. How do we kind of reconcile the actual financial number with the volume decline?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Mark. Let me just step back into 2010, where, in the third quarter, we're almost coming off of record residential sales with the preceding year, 2009, being almost at a decade low. We forecast based on a normalized basis, so we would smooth out th
componenttext: This is Mark. Let me just step back into 2010, where, in the third quarter, we're almost coming off of record residential sales with the preceding year, 2009, being almost at a decade low. We forecast based on a normalized basis, so we would smooth out those kinds of offsets. So I think that the answer is simply that we normalize our forecast, and you will see that, that benefit that we get from the residential side gets stripped out. And that has an effect on the overall forecast. We don't take the residential increase of 19% and then add another 2% or 3% or some percent to it. So we're very comfortable with the forecast. We think it's more than achievable, and we think it aligns with our overall strategy.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: So what you're saying, though -- I don't get why that forecast wouldn't be skewed negative.

componenttext: What was that, Jonathan?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I’m trying to understand why, given that the sales are down because of the very strong 2010, why there wouldn't be just a negative skew to that forecast, why it's sort of a flat number.
componenttext: I’m trying to understand why, given that the sales are down because of the very strong 2010, why there wouldn't be just a negative skew to that forecast, why it's sort of a flat number.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think one very clear reason is that we're not a regulated utility, and our FES sales group can increase or decrease that number. I don't know. Bill, do you have the...
componenttext: Well, I think one very clear reason is that we're not a regulated utility, and our FES sales group can increase or decrease that number. I don't know. Bill, do you have the...

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think -- Mark -- let me go back to the distribution side of it. I mean, I think what we're looking at, Jonathan, is that we predict normal conditions. We're predicting some improvement in the economy. That improvement could accelerate and have pos
componenttext: Well, I think -- Mark -- let me go back to the distribution side of it. I mean, I think what we're looking at, Jonathan, is that we predict normal conditions. We're predicting some improvement in the economy. That improvement could accelerate and have positive benefits to us, or the economy can turn more negative on us like it has over the last several years. And what we wanted to try to capture as we look at drivers for next year is I still think we're in a fairly uncertain economic environment as to whether or not industrial sales will continue to grow at the pace they are or whether or not the economy will suffer some retraction. That's what we've tried to reflect there. While we're comfortable at a normal kind of basis, there's still a lot of uncertainty with respect to what the impact the economy can have on our sales.

componenttext: That's how I'm looking at it. So I'm looking more towards a policy as to how we can grow that dividend going forward.

componenttext: Okay. And then could you just tell us based on this hedged price of $60.54, is that, as we look out -- I guess the curve is pretty much going along. I guess gas prices are much higher in '12 versus '11. But is that something which is maintainable going forward in '12, or is there -- as we look beyond that?

componenttext: Eventually, that number reflects the market. This number for '11 is as we've reflected, and our retail contracts will roll over at a ratable pace, about 10% a quarter roughly. The POLR contracts expire at predetermined dates. They're more lumpy. But in the long term, look 4 or 5 years down the road, that average revenue will reflect the market price as the contracts roll over.

componenttext: Okay. If I can just -- just to repeat that question another way, is the $60.54 above market right now, or is it pretty close to market if you were to re-contract it currently?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a fair reflection of the current market for the products involved in the contracts.
componenttext: It's a fair reflection of the current market for the products involved in the contracts.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Greg Gordon of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Greg Gordon of Morgan Stanley.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions as it relates to cash flow. I mean, you're clearly in a pretty strong cash flow position, notwithstanding the soft power market outlook. How much of that is coming from things like regulatory asset balances, and how long do you have
componenttext: A couple of questions as it relates to cash flow. I mean, you're clearly in a pretty strong cash flow position, notwithstanding the soft power market outlook. How much of that is coming from things like regulatory asset balances, and how long do you have to sort of benefit from those before they kind of run off? And is there also a benefit from bonus depreciation or any other things rolling into '11? Then I have another question after that.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm going to let Harvey deal with the bonus depreciation question, but I think you'll see that we have been extraordinarily aggressive in holding down our O&M expenses. We continue to do that. We continue to expect that to be the case next year and, by ho
componenttext: I'm going to let Harvey deal with the bonus depreciation question, but I think you'll see that we have been extraordinarily aggressive in holding down our O&M expenses. We continue to do that. We continue to expect that to be the case next year and, by holding that down, reducing our capital program, we'll continue to drive the free cash flow that we need to have. And I'll let Harvey deal with the bonus depreciation.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, just finishing up on the regulatory assets, we would expect that to continue for several more years. We still have the distribution deferrals in Ohio and some other things that are being collected through our rate surcharges. I'm sorry, the question
componenttext: Greg, just finishing up on the regulatory assets, we would expect that to continue for several more years. We still have the distribution deferrals in Ohio and some other things that are being collected through our rate surcharges. I'm sorry, the question on bonus depreciation?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did you benefit from it this year, by how much, and is there an assumption for any benefit next year?
componenttext: Did you benefit from it this year, by how much, and is there an assumption for any benefit next year?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, roughly about $180 million this year. And next year, whenever the Fremont plant is completed, we would expect somewhere in the $75 million to $80 million range.
componenttext: Yes, roughly about $180 million this year. And next year, whenever the Fremont plant is completed, we would expect somewhere in the $75 million to $80 million range.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great. My second question goes to credit metrics. As you talk to the rating agencies around credit, what are your target FFO-to-debt metrics, and where do you feel you guys are relative to those? This is a question that I think is becoming -- something th
componenttext: Great. My second question goes to credit metrics. As you talk to the rating agencies around credit, what are your target FFO-to-debt metrics, and where do you feel you guys are relative to those? This is a question that I think is becoming -- something that people are asking of a lot of diversified names, so I just wanted to know how you feel about your credit metrics relative to the current power market outlook.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't think our credit metrics are where they need to be. We're working to improve them. Obviously, generating free cash flow in the level of liquidity we have gives us near-term benefit. We've articulated in the past our desire to sell some non-core a
componenttext: We don't think our credit metrics are where they need to be. We're working to improve them. Obviously, generating free cash flow in the level of liquidity we have gives us near-term benefit. We've articulated in the past our desire to sell some non-core assets. Our merger with AYE is driven with equity. But you're correct. Our game plan is to improve those metrics, and we've been improving them on a quarterly basis, and we expect to continue to do so. And Jim speaks with the agencies quite often, so I think he can give you a little bit more one-on-one flavor.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Greg, I would agree with what Mark said there. Our goal is to incrementally keep improving those metrics on a quarterly basis. And if we do sell some of these non-core assets, we'll use those proceeds to pay down debt. So we would expect to continue
componenttext: Yes, Greg, I would agree with what Mark said there. Our goal is to incrementally keep improving those metrics on a quarterly basis. And if we do sell some of these non-core assets, we'll use those proceeds to pay down debt. So we would expect to continue to see those improvements.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: One other point is that when you look over at the utility side of the business, we try to keep their capital structure very closely in line with the regulatory rate structure.
componenttext: One other point is that when you look over at the utility side of the business, we try to keep their capital structure very closely in line with the regulatory rate structure.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from David Frank of Catapult.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from David Frank of Catapult.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two quick questions. One, could you give us an outlook on the retail electric market in Ohio? What are your shopping expectations -- or what are your expectations for shopping and opportunities, both in your service territory and those of your neighbors?
componenttext: Two quick questions. One, could you give us an outlook on the retail electric market in Ohio? What are your shopping expectations -- or what are your expectations for shopping and opportunities, both in your service territory and those of your neighbors? Are you seeing any new areas emerge? Or can you give us an update there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Without getting into the details, we're seeing opportunities not only within the traditional franchise areas but throughout the state of Ohio, and we're aggressively pursuing sales not only here in Ohio, but elsewhere. There isn't a -- I haven't seen the
componenttext: Without getting into the details, we're seeing opportunities not only within the traditional franchise areas but throughout the state of Ohio, and we're aggressively pursuing sales not only here in Ohio, but elsewhere. There isn't a -- I haven't seen the top to the market yet.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you can see that in some of my comments. We were 6.3 million megawatt hours above last year's period, a 45% increase, and half of those came from customers outside our traditional service territory and about 1/3 outside of utility service territor
componenttext: I think you can see that in some of my comments. We were 6.3 million megawatt hours above last year's period, a 45% increase, and half of those came from customers outside our traditional service territory and about 1/3 outside of utility service territory. So we're very pleased. It's all about margin, where we can get the highest margin. And if we can get that in a location outside of what would be deemed our traditional franchise territory, that's where we will try to push it. But right now, we're very pleased with what they're doing. They're structuring contracts. They're staggering them. They're giving us higher margin, and we would expect that to continue. We don't see any reason why it would not.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right. I guess, Tony, just your pick for who's going to win the governor election and thoughts on what it's going to mean longer term to the commission there?
componenttext: Right. I guess, Tony, just your pick for who's going to win the governor election and thoughts on what it's going to mean longer term to the commission there?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think either Mr. Strickland or Mr. Kasich will win, and I assume you were only talking about Ohio because there's multiple states that we are involved in.
componenttext: I think either Mr. Strickland or Mr. Kasich will win, and I assume you were only talking about Ohio because there's multiple states that we are involved in.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, Ohio.
componenttext: No, Ohio.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think it's going to be a very close race. The numbers have it different ways, depending on what polls you look at, so we will have a winner next Tuesday.
componenttext: And I think it's going to be a very close race. The numbers have it different ways, depending on what polls you look at, so we will have a winner next Tuesday.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Carrie Saint Louis of Fidelity.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Carrie Saint Louis of Fidelity.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I just wanted to turn and follow up on some topics. First of all, with respect to the non-core asset sales, any update on timing?
componenttext: So I just wanted to turn and follow up on some topics. First of all, with respect to the non-core asset sales, any update on timing?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's a good question, Carrie. We think we're going to sell a portion of the Fremont asset -- excuse me, OVEC, by the end of the year. That's fairly along. On the Signal Peak asset, we've always articulated that as its production gets up to the 100%
componenttext: Yes, that's a good question, Carrie. We think we're going to sell a portion of the Fremont asset -- excuse me, OVEC, by the end of the year. That's fairly along. On the Signal Peak asset, we've always articulated that as its production gets up to the 100% level, we'll accelerate that sale. They had a very strong third quarter. I think I've articulated in the past we brought in a new Chief Operating Officer who spends all of his time inside the mine. We've seen a dramatic increase in the production from Signal Peak, so on that asset, I would say sooner rather than later, probably, we hope maybe in the first quarter of next year, not too much beyond that. But again, it depends on their production schedule. We just don't want to get into a debate with a potential buyer as to what the actual production level is. And some of the other assets might be not as far along, but we're making progress.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I saw on the press release, I believe...
componenttext: Okay. And I saw on the press release, I believe...

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Carrie, I want to make clear one thing, that Signal Peak is a very valuable asset, and we are not exiting that business prematurely.
componenttext: Carrie, I want to make clear one thing, that Signal Peak is a very valuable asset, and we are not exiting that business prematurely.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I understand. I was just going to say I saw on the press release that I believe some debt financing has been put there or structured there. And so when you think about an asset sale there, does that -- that debt would move off with the asset, cor
componenttext: Yes. No, I understand. I was just going to say I saw on the press release that I believe some debt financing has been put there or structured there. And so when you think about an asset sale there, does that -- that debt would move off with the asset, correct?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we financed the original development of the mine. It was never our intent to be the permanent financing source. The market was attractive to do something. The production is far enough along that it's no longer considered kind of a startup development
componenttext: Yes, we financed the original development of the mine. It was never our intent to be the permanent financing source. The market was attractive to do something. The production is far enough along that it's no longer considered kind of a startup development. Jim's team was able to execute that. While the debt is still on our books, the cash now sits on our books. So Jim, do want to add any other...

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Carrie, this is Jim. We put in place a revolving credit facility down at Signal Peak. No matter what debt is outstanding at Signal Peak, we have to consolidate that on our balance sheet. We had been funding that operation with about $250 million from
componenttext: Yes, Carrie, this is Jim. We put in place a revolving credit facility down at Signal Peak. No matter what debt is outstanding at Signal Peak, we have to consolidate that on our balance sheet. We had been funding that operation with about $250 million from our revolving credit facility, so essentially, it freed up some of our liquidity. But once we sell the asset, if and when we do, it's really like 3 areas that'll help us. One, you will not consolidate that debt that's on the balance sheet right now, which is about $325 million. The excess cash over that debt that we get, we'll be able to use that to further pay down debt. And as Tony said, it's a very valuable asset. We would expect that we would generate a gain on our investment that would enhance our retained earnings.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay, fabulous. Okay. Then turning to the disclosure that you'd be giving more information at EEI, what information is that? And specifically, do you think it would include like the hedging outlook for 2012?
componenttext: Okay, fabulous. Okay. Then turning to the disclosure that you'd be giving more information at EEI, what information is that? And specifically, do you think it would include like the hedging outlook for 2012?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Carrie, this is Mark. We're going to just kind of take the questions we've gotten today, kind of sit around the table, try to get a sense of what additional information people want and then provide it. And I'm certain that Ron and Irene are going to get a
componenttext: Carrie, this is Mark. We're going to just kind of take the questions we've gotten today, kind of sit around the table, try to get a sense of what additional information people want and then provide it. And I'm certain that Ron and Irene are going to get a lot of questions as soon as the call is over. And our intent is to try to address as much of that as possible.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, then, here, I'll just throw something out then, too. Obviously, with respect to credit metrics, which have come into focus -- and you mentioned your regulated op cos are capitalized in agreement with your regulatory structure. I think investor
componenttext: Okay. Well, then, here, I'll just throw something out then, too. Obviously, with respect to credit metrics, which have come into focus -- and you mentioned your regulated op cos are capitalized in agreement with your regulatory structure. I think investors tend to quickly look at the consolidated metrics versus kind of focusing on the different parts which are capitalized differently. So what is the outlook at Solutions, when in terms of, like, metrics, and what is your commitment there? My sense is that you guys have been very firm about maintaining investment-grade metrics at Solutions, if not better, and I just wanted to kind of get reiteration of that view from you.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think you stated it right on the button. We expect to maintain investment-grade ratings, if not better, and our target is to move them to the better category. I think you -- that was well stated.
componenttext: I think you stated it right on the button. We expect to maintain investment-grade ratings, if not better, and our target is to move them to the better category. I think you -- that was well stated.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Hugh Wynne of Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Hugh Wynne of Sanford Bernstein.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was looking at your consolidated income or consolidating income statement, I guess, it is on Page 9, where you compare earnings of energy delivery services to competitive energy services…
componenttext: I was looking at your consolidated income or consolidating income statement, I guess, it is on Page 9, where you compare earnings of energy delivery services to competitive energy services…

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hugh, could you speak up just a little?
componenttext: Hugh, could you speak up just a little?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. I was looking at Page 9, at a consolidating income statement there. I noticed that energy delivery services this year looks like it's going to contribute almost 3/4 of earnings. Now my question really related to dividend policy post-merger. Some com
componenttext: Sure. I was looking at Page 9, at a consolidating income statement there. I noticed that energy delivery services this year looks like it's going to contribute almost 3/4 of earnings. Now my question really related to dividend policy post-merger. Some companies with a similar composition of earnings will link the dividend to the regulated earnings of the company. So I guess my question is this: How do you see the composition of earnings across delivery services and energy services developing post-merger? And then second, what would be the guiding factors in your advice to the board regarding a dividend policy? Is this one of the considerations, or are others -- have a greater weight in your thinking?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Hugh, I think we're looking long term probably closer to 50% out of the wire side of the business and 50% out of the generation side of the business, so we'll just see how that plays out. My own sense is everything you just talked about will be some
componenttext: Well, Hugh, I think we're looking long term probably closer to 50% out of the wire side of the business and 50% out of the generation side of the business, so we'll just see how that plays out. My own sense is everything you just talked about will be something that we think about and consider as we try to design an appropriate policy and communicate that policy to our investors at some point. At this point, I'm not really prepared to discuss any of the specific things that we would look to, but obviously, the proportion of regulated versus competitive would be part of what we would look at.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hugh, I would only add that when you get to the consolidated company of FirstEnergy and AYE, you're going to have a transmission piece in the middle that will be also throwing off substantial earnings. And so that all has to get placed into the mix. And u
componenttext: Hugh, I would only add that when you get to the consolidated company of FirstEnergy and AYE, you're going to have a transmission piece in the middle that will be also throwing off substantial earnings. And so that all has to get placed into the mix. And until we get all of that finalized with the transition teams, we're still a little bit ahead of the curve.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Hugh, this is Harvey Wagner. I'd also just remind you that the impairment charges associated with the Lake plants distorted that comparative impact among the segments for the 9 months.
componenttext: Hugh, this is Harvey Wagner. I'd also just remind you that the impairment charges associated with the Lake plants distorted that comparative impact among the segments for the 9 months.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question is coming from Jeff Coviello of Duquesne Capital.
componenttext: Our next question is coming from Jeff Coviello of Duquesne Capital.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's John [ph] actually. I just wanted to go back to your comments that -- you made a couple of comments, I guess, earlier in the call, one that sounded like there was no risk of a dividend cut, and then you also mentioned the need that you saw for credit
componenttext: It's John [ph] actually. I just wanted to go back to your comments that -- you made a couple of comments, I guess, earlier in the call, one that sounded like there was no risk of a dividend cut, and then you also mentioned the need that you saw for credit metric improvement. And then finally, you talked a little bit about -- or you alluded to a more formal dividend policy that accounts for volatility after the Allegheny deal. So my first question is, have the rating agencies commented on the level of dividend payout over the next several years and in combination with the pace at which you need to de-lever to maintain that investment-grade rating or that low BBB rating at FirstEnergy Solutions? Can you talk a little bit about how you...

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: John [ph], I don't believe so, and Jim is shaking his head no, so...
componenttext: John [ph], I don't believe so, and Jim is shaking his head no, so...

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: We haven't had any specific conversations about the dividend policy, John [ph].
componenttext: We haven't had any specific conversations about the dividend policy, John [ph].

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't want to speculate, but I assume that if our cash flow wasn't as strong as it was, we might have that question, but not with the cash flow we're now generating.
componenttext: I don't want to speculate, but I assume that if our cash flow wasn't as strong as it was, we might have that question, but not with the cash flow we're now generating.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Got it. And what did you mean by a more formal dividend policy that accounts for volatility? What did volatility mean?
componenttext: Got it. And what did you mean by a more formal dividend policy that accounts for volatility? What did volatility mean?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess the easiest way to explain that, John [ph], is when you think about a competitive business in which the market price, just even here a couple of years ago, was, pick a number, 15. Now it's 30. When you have that type of movement, if you had
componenttext: Well, I guess the easiest way to explain that, John [ph], is when you think about a competitive business in which the market price, just even here a couple of years ago, was, pick a number, 15. Now it's 30. When you have that type of movement, if you had a policy that just said you're going to send a percentage of earnings out, then when the market is very, very good, the dividend is high, but when the market is not as good, then the dividend has to be cut to reflect that. I don't think that's a policy that we would endorse. We would be looking for something that would be able to be sustainable and be maintained in whatever economic environment we face for the long term. So that's what we'd be looking at, and that's what I mean by it.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then so that, consistent with your earlier comment, means that at the current level of dividend paid out in cents per share, I guess, effectively, your dollars per share, that you're very confident that, that is sustainable based on the amount o
componenttext: Okay. And then so that, consistent with your earlier comment, means that at the current level of dividend paid out in cents per share, I guess, effectively, your dollars per share, that you're very confident that, that is sustainable based on the amount of de-levering you need to do and the target to maintain an investment-grade rating at FirstEnergy Solutions. I was trying to understand what exactly you meant there, please.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer would be yes.
componenttext: The answer would be yes.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: Our next question is coming from Steve Fleishman of Bank of America.

componenttext: This was really Greg Gordon's question just asked again. The amount of the 2011 operating cash flow that is for recovery of deferrals, how much is that?

componenttext: Okay. So that number will be -- I mean, full year number this year might be $700 million, but it'll be dramatically lower next year.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right.
componenttext: Right.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our last question is coming from Paul Fremont of Jefferies & Company.
componenttext: Our last question is coming from Paul Fremont of Jefferies & Company.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at the capital spending, should I assume that you guys have made a decision not to scrub any of the coal plants that currently don't have either scrubbers or SCRs, or is that a potential future call on your spending?
componenttext: Looking at the capital spending, should I assume that you guys have made a decision not to scrub any of the coal plants that currently don't have either scrubbers or SCRs, or is that a potential future call on your spending?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we've made any decision related to that. We have transition teams working now looking at the generation of AYE, what it would cost to increase their capacity factors, reduce down their forced outage rates. And when that team makes a recommen
componenttext: I don't think we've made any decision related to that. We have transition teams working now looking at the generation of AYE, what it would cost to increase their capacity factors, reduce down their forced outage rates. And when that team makes a recommendation, we'll be in a great position to answer that. But right now, they're looking at both systems and where would be the best place to deploy the least amount of capital to get the most bang for your dollar.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the capital spending could go up if you decide to scrub any or all of the unscrubbed units, right?
componenttext: Okay. So the capital spending could go up if you decide to scrub any or all of the unscrubbed units, right?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, it also could go down as we elect not to spend money on our units because their unit is in a cost range and dispatching range where we wouldn't spend it on our side. So it could go either way. Our game plan is not to, again, spend money where we can'
componenttext: Yes, it also could go down as we elect not to spend money on our units because their unit is in a cost range and dispatching range where we wouldn't spend it on our side. So it could go either way. Our game plan is not to, again, spend money where we can't get a more immediate benefit that neither of us could get independently.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: On your second quarter call, you had talked at Signal Peak about targeting a production level of 600,000 tons per month. Is that where you currently are in the third quarter, or can you give us a sense of what the production level is?
componenttext: On your second quarter call, you had talked at Signal Peak about targeting a production level of 600,000 tons per month. Is that where you currently are in the third quarter, or can you give us a sense of what the production level is?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the production level is a touch below that, but it's on a ramp up. I think the raw tonnage in September was 900,000, but that's got to be washed. So that was probably down 650,000, 700,000. The more important feature to me is it's increasing drama
componenttext: I think the production level is a touch below that, but it's on a ramp up. I think the raw tonnage in September was 900,000, but that's got to be washed. So that was probably down 650,000, 700,000. The more important feature to me is it's increasing dramatically every month now that we have someone that's a mine expert sitting in the mine every day. We just decided that we had the CEO, John DeMichiei, maybe spread a little too thin. He did a fabulous job developing the mine, but he can't get in the mine every day. The new gentleman is, and he's doing great, and you're seeing that in the production levels.

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010
componenttextpreview: One of the production issues that I think we need to at least highlight for you is that we are now in the first longwall panel. That will be moved in April -- March, April time frame into the second panel. The second panel is a much more -- a much higher
componenttext: One of the production issues that I think we need to at least highlight for you is that we are now in the first longwall panel. That will be moved in April -- March, April time frame into the second panel. The second panel is a much more -- a much higher seam. And therefore, if you get those types of production numbers, you get a much better clean product coming out because you're not taking as much ancillary product along with you. So it really is part of this overall development as you move through the initial panel into the panels that will, in fact, be the long-term future of that mine.

As you ramp up that production that's capable of delivering once you move it through the wash facility at a higher recovery rate, your numbers come naturally.

componenttext: And my last question is -- I guess Mark had talked about sort of being comfortable with the payout level on the 2011 earnings. Should we assume that there's no further potential deterioration in earnings beyond '11 or if, in fact, the earnings level were to go lower in some of the out years, would that not result in a significantly or potentially higher payout level than what you could see in 2011?

headline: FirstEnergy Corp., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2010

componenttext: I think we'll give 2012 guidance, as Tony alluded to, in that time frame. But my only response to the prior question was we've got $500-plus million projected free cash flow after paying the dividend, and it was -- I think the question was related specifically to '11, and we responded specifically. But we'll give the '12 in the time frame that Tony alluded to.
